transcripts.text: Hi, I'm Eduardo Naret with Campus Reform.  Today we're at the University of South Florida asking students if they think illegal immigrants should have access to taxpayer-funded free tuition.  When the students tell me yes, I'm going to be asking them if they would be willing to put their own money towards the cause.  Let's find out what they say.  Do you believe education is a human right?
Yes.
Yes, because I believe everyone should have the opportunity to get access to education.
Education is what lets people know about.
It's necessary.  Education is for everyone.  It's not just for selected people.  Everyone should have the opportunity to at least get some type of education.
Without education, a person is not able to experience what society has built to the fullest.

Yes, absolutely.  Education is the key to upward mobility.  It's the key to life.  It's the key to being successful.  Without education, you don't know what's going on around you.  You don't know what you need, like what you need to survive, basically.  So, yeah, absolutely.  Education is definitely a human right.

We've heard a lot of discussions recently in the news and politics about, you know, using taxpayer money for free tuition for everyone.  So do you personally believe undocumented immigrants should have access, should have taxpayer free tuition?
Absolutely.  I think undocumented immigrants have a negative connotation attached toward them, and they come to this country seeking a better life.
I actually do agree because I believe everybody should have an equal opportunity to get the right education.  These kind of resources shouldn't be limited to people that are undocumented.

If it is a human right, then we naturally have to give it to the immigrants, right?  If you do give education to the undocumented immigrants, you're going to increase the quality of the labor force.  So that's going to result in a higher GDP and it's going to benefit the economy.
Would you support free college for undocumented people in this country?
Yeah, definitely.  I would.  Yeah, 100%.  I think it's very difficult for a lot of undocumented children to basically have a good stand in this country without it.  It's not really fair for them.

I myself would argue that immigrants deserve to be illegal.  They deserve education as a human right.  Because I truly, truly believe that the amount of illegal immigrants compared to the resources this country has, you know, they cancel each other out to provide enough education for everyone.
I think it's always nice to help people.  I'm never against helping people, whether they're documented or not.  I'm with it, 100%, to be honest.
And they deserve that human right of education.

So I'm glad you said that, because something we're doing today is we are trying to raise money for tuition for undocumented immigrants since they don't have access.  So would you be willing to give some money for that tuition?
If I did, I definitely would.  But your girl is broke, so yeah.
I'll have to pass on that one.
But it's a human right though.
It is a human right, absolutely.
Do you think you're violating their human rights then by not chipping in?
Emotional appeal.  Well, I mean, no, it's a human right for me to say no, right?
Since they can't get it through taxpayer dollars, would you guys be willing to contribute?
I would love to, but I don't have cash on me right now.
I don't have cash on me either right now, but I would love to.
Do you guys have Venmo?
I don't.  I don't.  I don't have money on me, though.

Oh, you don't have money on you?  What about Venmo?  I mean, come on, because education is a human right.  You don't have Venmo?  No.  Because you seemed interested, would you be willing to give money?
I have no cash on me at all.
Venmo?
Sure, yeah, I'll give a Venmo.

Right now I have my Bulls card in my pocket and I haven't eaten in two days because I have no money.  It shouldn't be my duty to raise the money, to tell you that.  This country has more than enough money distributed in the hands of the wrong individuals.

Hey there, I'm Eduardo Naret with Campus Reform.  If you're interested in subscribing to get our latest content, click here.
